Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Safer Connected Communities Through Integrated Data-driven Modeling, Learning, and Optimization

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Crime is a major problem in many urban communities. This project focuses on developing a framework for increased security and crime prevention in crime-prone environments by identifying and integrating hitherto disaggregated heterogeneous data and analyzing the causal and spatio-temporal interconnections between constituent parts of a connected community including environmental aspects (i.e., traffic, lighting, poverty levels, business proximity such as banks/ATMs), crime history, and social events. While existing crime prediction and prevention methods focus on the location of the crimes to detect ``hot-zones'', this project takes a fundamentally different, data-driven approach towards integrated multi-scale data analytics for identifying the characteristics and features of crime-prone environments. This high-risk high-payoff project research is based on real-time crime data and interactions with crime prevention and safety agencies. By revealing the connections between crime and environmental, social, and economic factors, this research aims to demonstrate the critical need of an integrated systems approach to crime prevention, instead of focusing on post-crisis management.

This interdisciplinary endeavor of developing computational methods for crime prevention across public urban landscapes requires the combination of data mining and statistical methods in space and time to extract useful features and discover models from passive data sets. The proposed project will develop 1) new tools for the fundamental understanding of criminal behavior by analyzing the time varying and location-specific systems and patterns observed as a result of complex processes between interacting cyber-physical entities, and 2) scalable data-driven Nowcasting algorithms for crime prediction that will adapt with the constantly evolving state of criminal activity by continuously learning from a rich set of spatial and demographic features, including traffic, spatial attributes, socio-economic characteristics of neighborhoods, and current time, as well as context. To enable continuous forecasting over streaming data, while maintaining high prediction accuracy and low time complexity, the project will develop and train crime prediction artificial neural networks (CANN) for prediction across space and time. The output of the proposed data-driven models will feed a novel multi-objective optimization formulation that will be used for the integrated optimization of personnel positioning, patrol scheduling and safest route calculation. The resulting decision support environment, will be transferred to the USC Department of Public Safety (DPS), the Los Angeles Police Department (LAPD), and South Park Business Improvement District (SPBID) for integration with their systems to enable decision makers to choose the best course of action at any given time.

This project will lead to the development of technology for crime prevention that will be directly applicable to smart and connected communities across the US, with the potential to bring together white and blue-collar residents from mixed urban communities- college campus residents, off-campus neighborhood residents and businesses with their employees, transiting commuters and law enforcement under the theme of making the communities quantifiably more secure. The project will leverage the USC Living Laboratory, a unique ?city within a city? campus and its adjacent neighborhoods as a real-world use case of a connected community of interrelated infrastructures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: The project developed data-driven techniques for helping create a safer community. The project explored two main directions: crime prediction at the university and city-scale, and violence prevention among the disadvantaged community. The project developed clustering-based spatio-temporal forecasting techniques and showed that this approach outperformed traditional spatio-temporal techniques used in crime prediction. It also demonstrated that there was a lack of evaluation metrics that can appropriately compare various forecasting strategies. To mitigate this issue, a novel practical evaluation metric was proposed which, instead of computing errors, measures the estimated advantage of using forecasts to deploy police resources. A decision support tool was developed hat can be used by public safety officials to (i) visualize past crime patterns by type, time, day, and location, (ii) perform crime predictions using the techniques developed during the project, and (iii) evaluate multiple techniques to analyze which technique is more reliable for basing decisions on. The tool also provides an "expert mode" option by offering the capability to tune some parameters of our techniques and run them on filtered datasets to create and analyze different prediction models.
The project also led to a collaboration with the Department of Social Work at the University of Sothern California, in which a networked-data-driven peer-selection method was developed to conduct interventions. Specifically, the project considered a network of homeless youth with the target of minimizing violence. A novel diffusion model was developed that captures the diffusion of violent behavior in the community while accounting for various uncertainties in the data. Based on this model, an algorithm was derived to identify peers for intervention that can result in the maximum reduction in violence. These identified peers were (i) "well-connected" in their network, (ii) violent themselves, and (iii) open to the chosen intervention. The pilot study using this approach at a youth shelter, based on pre and post-intervention surveys showed a 40% reduction in violence.


Broader Impact: The project has led to research and tools that directly impact society. The crime prevention decision support tool can be used by public officials to plan deployments based on accurate forecasts, thus making the community safer. The work on peer-selection for violence minimization was demonstrated in the real-world through a pilot study. Reducing violence is essential for the homeless youth to safely and successfully exit homelessness and lead a long productive life. The networked-data-based approach for peer-selection can be applied to other issues in the disadvantaged community. New collaborations have been created with the Department of Social Work, the USC Homeless Initiative, and local organizations serving disadvantaged communities to apply these algorithms to improve employment and housing situation. This project brought together experts in computer science, social work, psychology, and public policy, and stakeholders including public safety personnel and various organizations serving disadvantaged communities. The project supported a PhD student and played a key role in his thesis. The project also provided research and development opportunities to undergraduate students in the form of directed research and two Capstone projects.
